ğŸŒ³ Example 1: A Leaf on a Tree
Imagine a maple tree leaf on a sunny day:
Water: roots absorb water â†’ transported up through xylem to the leaves.
COâ‚‚: enters through tiny pores under the leaf (stomata).
Sunlight: hits chloroplasts in leaf cells.
Inside chloroplasts:
Light reactions make ATP, NADPH and release Oâ‚‚.
Calvin cycle uses ATP, NADPH, and COâ‚‚ to make glucose.
What happens to the glucose?
Some is used right away for cellular respiration (to produce energy for growth, repair, etc.)
Some is stored as:
Starch in roots or stems
Cellulose to build cell walls (trunk, branches, etc.)

In a potato plant:
Leaves do photosynthesis and produce glucose.
Glucose is transported down through the phloem to the underground stem (the potato).
There it is converted to starch and stored.
So the potato you eat is basically:
Packed energy made from sunlight + air + water ğŸ½ï¸
